description.narrative: The project aims to address a range of institutional, governance and financial issues that presently prevent the project objective from being achieved.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1. Capacity Development Score 1.2. SMART-RBM Threat Encounter Reports 1.3. Law Enforcement Patrol Effort 1.4. Forest Degradation Rates 1.5. Management Effectiveness (METT Score) 2.1. Number of Wildlife Crime Cases Submitted for Prosecution 2.2. Number of Agency Staff participating in Pilot Projects 2.3. Tiger, Prey and Forest Habitat Monitoring System 2.4. Human-Tiger Conflict Report Assessments / Responses 3.1. Financing Plans Five new financing plans in place for selected target PAs by the project end and budgets increased by 10%. 3.2. Sustainable Financing Plans for Production Areas involving PPPs 3.3. Financial Sustainability Scorecard Increase by >25% for each of the three component scores in the Financial Sustainability Scorecard for the sub-system of Sumatra’s protected areas

1. Completed project terminal evaluation and developed its management response. 2. Conducted a national hybrid seminar on the Sumatran Tiger Conservation to disseminate project key results and lesson learned. 3. Finalization of the project exit strategy. 4. Completed the last handover project report to Implementing Partner. 5. Completed HACT internal audit. 6. Timely completion of the project closure.

1. The project terminal evaluation and its management response have been completed and uploaded in the ERC system. 2. The seminar was conducted at Andalas University, Padang, West Sumatera and virtually on 14 Feb 2022. It was opened by the Governor of West Sumatera and the DG of KSDAE. The event was successfully attended by 650 people from government institutions both at national and sub-national levels, non-government organizations, universities, researchers, and UNDP. 3. The project exit strategy has been completed and available in Bahasa Indonesia and English versions.

Key Result 1.1: Management capacity increase through training Key Result 1.2: Enhanced Management and annual work plan developed, adopted, and implemented Key Result 1.3: SMART Patrol Implemented Key Result 1.4: METT annualy tracked Key Result 1.5: Update and adopted NTRP and Sumatran Tiger Conservation Action Plan Key Result 2.1: Landscape level and inter landscape partnerships developed and operazionalized concerning IWT Key Result 2.2: Innovative forest wildlife management intervention documented and reviewed for replication and upscaling Key Result 2.3: Tiger, Prey and Forest Habitat Monitoring System Key Result 2.4: Human-Tiger Conflict (HTC) Report Assessments / Responses Key Result 3.1: Financial sustainability anlysis conducted to improve cost-effectiveness, disbursement mechanism and budget resources for UPT Key Result 3.2: Sustainable financing plan developed and implemented for selection production areas through business and biodiversity mechanism Key Result 3.3: Institutional framework at national level adopted to support sustainable financing sheme implementation

Component 1 1. Project assessment of CD scorecards is finalised 2. Project target rate of number of illegal activities recorded per year per 100 km patrolled in each PA; and construction of tiger sanctuary in priority area is started 3. Project target number of forest patrol kilometres walked per year in PA and adjacent forests is reached 4.Final forest cover assessment completed. Deforestation rates target to be <1% by PY5 5.project METT Target scores for 5 target NPs; METT introduced as routine monitoring system for national PA system
Outcome 2: 1. Project target number of arrests in project landscapes are completed 2. Continued site exchange visits / training for targeted stakeholder audiences and promotion of replication / upscaling; total of at least 25 key stakeholders trained 3.Biological monitoring systems in place and operational at five target NPs by end of project 4. >95% of human-tiger conflict reports are correctly assessed and/or responded to in accordance with KSDAE mitigation protocol
Component 3 1. Multi - donor workshop convened by KSDAE for supporting key aspects of the National Tiger Recovery Plan; New financing plans in place for the 5 target NPs by end of project and budgets increased by 10%. 2. 2 (two) sustainable financing plans received funding and activity implementation begins 3. Measurement on project target scores on financial sustainability is finalised.

Targets: 1.1. End of project assessment of CD scorecards - see targets in the inset table in SRF. 1.2. See inset table in SRF for end of project target rate of number of illegal activities recorded per year per 100km patrolled in each PA; tiger sanctuary is established and fully operationalized. 1.3. See inset table in SRF for end of project target number of forest patrol kilometres walked per year in PA and adjacent forests. 1.4. Final forest cover assessment completed. See inset table for end of project deforestation rates targets. 1.5. See inset table in SRF for end of project METT Target scores for 5 target NPs; METT introduced as routine monitoring system for national PA system.
Targets: 2.1. See inset table in SRF for end of project target number of arrests in project landscapes. 2.2. Continued site exchange visits / training for targeted stakeholder audiences and promotion of replication / upscaling; total of at least 25 key stakeholders trained. 2.3. Biological monitoring systems in place and operational at five target NPs by end of project. 2.4. >95% of human-tiger conflict reports are correctly assessed and/or responded to in accordance with KSDAE mitigation protocol P48.
Targets: 3.1. Multi - donor workshop convened by KSDAE for supporting key aspects of the National Tiger Recovery Plan; New financing plans in place for the 5 target NPs by end of project budgets increased by 10% 3.2. 2 sustainable financing plans received funding and activity implementation begins. 3.3. See inset table for end of project target scores on financial sustainability.

Main indicator: Final report of the Sumatran tiger density: the overall estimated figure in this reporting period is still below the EOP Target and shows a decreasing trend as compared to the earlier period. This was happened due to introduction of new methodology in assessing the tiger density which was different with the tool at the baseline level.
Output 1.1.: The overall CDSCs progress is considered on track, with progress towards the end project target level at 95.1% overall in all targeted sites Output 1.2: Progress towards the end project target level at 100% overall in all targeted sites. The tiger-related threats has been overall reduced by an estimated of 72.2% in the 5 targeted regions (of four administered National Parks) indicated by a reduction in the number of illegal activities. Output 1.3: This progress indicator is considered as on track, with progress towards the end project target level at 84% (overall in five regions of four administered National Parks). Output 1.4: The progress is 100% achieved its target level. All targeted National Parks have achieved <1% forest degradation rate Output 1.5: This progress indicator is considered on track, with 98.4% target has been overall achieved. Three of the four NPs, namely Berbak Sembilang, Kerinci Seblat and Bukit Barisan Selatan, have already achieved their EOP targets Output 2.1: Progress towards the end project target level at 100% in all targeted sites. The indicator progress for inter-sector collaboration has been fully achieved in this reporting period (exceeding the EOP Target). Output 2.2: Progress towards the end project target level at 100%. In this reporting period, the target for this indicator has been fully achieved. Output 2.3: Progress towards the end project target level at 100%. For this indicator, project has fully achieved the EOP target: standardized tiger, prey and forest habitat monitoring system has been developed and operationalized for the targeted landscapes and their surroundings Output 2.4: Progress towards the end project target level at 100%. In this reporting period, project is confident that all human-tiger conflict incidents in all project landscapes and surrounding areas were responded properly to meet P.48 protocol Output 3.1: Progress towards the end project target level at 100% for the targeted indicator Output 3.2: Two sustainable financing plans have been developed and consulted with relevant stakeholders and currently on the final stage of finalization Output 3.3: The progress status for the indicator is considered as 100% achieved. The three components of the Financial Sustainability Score Card have overall increased by 88%. Therefore, the targeted increase by > 25% have been fully achieved

See inset table for end of project deforestation rates targets. 1.5. Targets: 3.1. Multi - donor workshop convened by KSDAE for supporting key aspects of the National Tiger Recovery Plan; New financing plans in place for the 5 target NPs by end of project budgets increased by 10% 3.2. 2 sustainable financing plans received funding and activity implementation begins. 3.3. This year the project has achieved main indicator on biodiversity protection with average score for 4 landscapes (Sembilang data is excluded) is 1.41 /100 km2. All target national parks have carried out the CD scorecard assessment. The threat encounter reports reduced in Gunung Leuser and Kerinci Seblat national parks. The project has supported the patrols at 4 national parks and as the result, the patrols has passed the EOP. Forest degradation were increased at 3 national parks, unless the GLNP. METT scores also increase and passed the EOP.
In 2020, 13 cases were submitted for prosecution , exceeded the EOP target of 9 cases per year. Sumatran Tiger Project also facilitated participation of 128 staff of the Ministry of Environment and Forestry, Provincial/District level authorities and/or regional development planning authorities. The monitoring system developed by Sumatran Tiger Project in each landscape will help the protection mechanism of animals. Moreover, Human - Tiger Conflict and other Human - WIldlife Conflict handled, reported, and well documented.
The Ministry of PPN / Bappenas completed a business plan / funding road map for the Kerinci Seblat National Park TNKS and moreover, has developed a strategy to integrate Kerinci Seblat National Parks (TNKS) program with the buffer zones managed by Forest Management Unit (KPH), the community and the private sector. The intervention would contribute to integrated efforts made by jet stakeholders for biodiversity protection in Indonesia. To strengthen the management of protection, there were 3 (three) main components reviewed in the Financial Sustainability Score Card, are (1) regulatory and institutional frameworks, (2) business models to support effective management, and (3) revenue generating schemes.
